title: Chelsea news: Frank Lampard describes Jose Mourinho and Carlo Ancelotti impact
text:
Frank Lampard has been managed by some of the greats (Picture: Getty Images)

Frank Lampard has picked out some of the management styles of Jose Mourinho and Carlo Ancelotti that he is trying to take on board in his time as Chelsea boss.

The Blues legend is finding his feet impressively as the manager at Stamford Bridge, leading his team to six straight victories in all competitions.

Now fourth in the Premier League, and top of their Champions League group, things are going very nicely for the rookie manager, who had just one year of experience as a boss to his name before taking the Chelsea job, and that came with Derby in the Championship.

The 41-year-old played under some of the most successful managers in modern football, and while he credits all of them with helping him succeed, he picked out Mourinho and Ancelotti as particular role models.

‘All of them, as you say, have helped me for good and for bad,’ Lampard told Sky Sports when asked about how his previous bosses have influenced him. ‘When I say that I mean things that I thought as a player “that was great” and I’ve taken it on board and some you think “I’m not so mad on that”.

‘Jose Mourinho was obviously a huge influence on me when he first came to the club, he gave me a real uplift in confidence, more than tactics or technical stuff it was more how good could I be and did I have the mindset to move up levels.

Jose Mourinho has had a huge impact on Frank Lampard’s career (Picture: Getty Images)

‘Carlo Ancelotti I always found in terms of how personable a manager can be, their relationship with you one-on-one, to try and get the best out of you, so those two I tend to say a lot but I feel bad leaving out a lot of the other managers I had because all had positive influences in me in their own ways.’

Lampard will be looking to keep up his team’s impressive run of form on Saturday when Chelsea travel to Burnley in the Premier League in the 5.30pm kick-off.

The Blues have been free-scoring under their new manager, netting 19 times in nine Premier League games, and are now tightening up at the back, with three clean sheets in their last five across all competitions.

The Clarets will pose a tough test for the former England international and he will be looking to employ all the tricks Mourinho and Ancelotti taught him to come through it.
